panels.description: How many messages per second materialized is currently ingesting
panels.title: Kafka Message Ingest Rate

panels.description: A record is equivalent to a row in a traditional database
panels.title: Total Number of Records

panels.description: Total number of sql data queries being executed per second.
panels.title: Client queries per second

panels.description: the view of how long things took, from inside pgwire
panels.title: command=$command server latency quantiles

panels.description:
Unlike the Messages Ingested by Format, this shows the raw number of messages we've received

Currently only shows Kafka
panels.title: Kafka Messages Ingested

panels.description: The raw kafka offset as seen at ingest time by materialized.
panels.title: Kafka Offsets Received

panels.description:
This shows the number of messages that materialize knows it is behind an external source.

For example, if there are 1,000 messages in kafka and materialized has processed 750, this value will be 250
panels.title: Messages behind external source

panels.description:
The total number of times that a source has been scheduled, and the rate at which they're scheduled.

In a well-behaved system, sources should be activated approximately in proportion to how much data they have to read. If sources are being scheduled at significantly different proportions it could mean that the more-scheduled sources are having a hard time keeping up.
panels.title: Source Scheduled Count

panels.description: This is only reported for Kinesis sources at the moment.
panels.title: Time behind external source

panels.description:
This shows the top 10 dataflow operators that are introducing lag into the system.

An operator can introduce lag either because its source is running behind, or because it is doing lots of work.
panels.title: Frontier lags

panels.description:
A worker is the underlying thread of computation in materialized. In general materialized should send similar amounts of work to each worker, and the queue depths should be similar to each other.

If a queue is growing without bound, or queues are very unbalanced, that could signify a problem.
panels.title: Worker queue sizes

panels.description:
In a healthy system this should converge to a value that oscillates between 0 and the configured timestamp frequency.

Under the hood, this is the difference between allocated timestamps and closed timestamps.
panels.title: Timestamp Closing Lag

panels.description:
This is a measure of when we last stated that ingested data was valid for computation. Another way of thinking about this is how many seconds of data do we ingest per second of real time. In a steady state this should be approximately 1s/s.

All sources that have a rate of 0 are *stalled* and are either not ingesting new data or have no new data to ingest.

Internally, this is the capability, and the underlying measure is what capability we have released.
panels.title: Capability Closing Rate

panels.description: The difference between the most-consumed and least-consumed kafka partition, in terms of when we last released messages into the dataflow layer.

targets.expr: max by (topic, source_id) (mz_kafka_partition_closed_ts) - min by (topic, source_id) (mz_kafka_partition_closed_ts)

panels.title: Partition Imbalance Amount

panels.description:
A batch is a slab of memory, arrangements with a large number of batches have allocated a large number of records, which should be represented in the Arrangement Records panel.

This shows the top 10 arrangements by number of batches, and should be similar to the Arrangement Records panel.
panels.title: Arrangement Batches

panels.description:
An arrangement is where materialize stores state, records are equivalent to rows in a database or messages in a stream.

This shows the top 10 arrangements by number of records, and should be similar to the Arrangement Batches panel.
panels.title: Arrangement Records
